Award.AbstractNarration:
This project by teams at the University of Alaska and the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry will engage the public in the topic of the nature and prevalence of permafrost, its scale on the earth and the important role it plays in the global climate. It builds on 50 years of informal education and outreach at the Alaskan Permafrost Tunnel near Fairbanks, AK, which, since the 1960s, has been the Nation's only underground facility for research related to permafrost and climate. The project has four components: (1) a nationally distributed 2,000 square-foot traveling exhibition; (2) exhibit and program enhancements to the learning opportunities at the tunnel; (3) programs, table-top exhibits and oral history research in 27 Native Alaskan villages; and (4) an education research study. Each of these components will be evaluated over the course of the work. By upgrading the displays at the tunnel, and by taking traveling programs to the villages, the work will extend the tunnel experience across Alaska. In the villages the team will collect stories about climate change, along with samples of real ancient ice and permafrost. These stories and materials will be used in the travelling exhibit which is expected to be at three museums per year for eight years.

The research component of the initiative will build on the observation to date that the tunnel has provided thousands of visitors with an underground immersive environment where they learn about the science research being conducted and engage with climate-sensitive materials (e.g., permafrost, wedge ice, frozen silt, Pleistocene bones) using all of their senses. It has been conjectured that their learning experiences are enhanced by interacting with real vs. replicated objects. As museums often contain exhibits that are more likely to contain replicated and/or virtual objects and environments, understanding the impact that these different categories of objects have on learning is important. Using both types of materials, the project will investigate differences in their efficacy in informal science learning institutions related to climate change. Real objects are postulated to have the following attributes that stimulate fuller engagement; they are (1) information-rich by virtue of such features as their texture, odor, and dimensionality; (2) at real-life scale; (3) authentic, i.e., original objects; and (4) often unique, i.e., have inherent value. Research questions will explore the potential impacts on learning of these and related features. Methods employed will be observation, video, and interviews of the public with a particular focus on visitor talk with respect to explanations and elaborations about permafrost, tipping points, climate change, and geological time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Oregon Museum of Science & Industry (OMSI) and the Geophysical Institute at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) partnered on the collaborative project, The Hidden World of Permafrost, funded by the National Science Foundation. OMSI's award (#1423587) focused on the production of Under the Arctic, a traveling exhibition for North American audiences. UAF's award (#1423550) focused on outreach programs for Alaska Native villages and learning research. OMSI and UAF worked together on all aspects of the collaborative project.

The Hidden World of Permafrost explores the interrelationship between thawing permafrost and climate change. It builds on 50 years of informal education and outreach at the Alaskan Permafrost Tunnel, the Nation's only underground facility for research related to permafrost and climate. OMSI collaborated with permafrost researchers and educators at UAF and Alaska Native advisors to create:

  • A 2,000-square-foot traveling exhibition, titled Under the Arctic: Digging into Permafrost
  • An exhibition website: https://omsi.edu/products/under-the-arctic
  • An Educator Guide to the exhibition for museum educators and classroom teachers
  • A supply of 30,000-year-old ice chunks from the permafrost research tunnel as an optional resource for tour sites
  • A 2018 STEM for All video about the exhibition http://stemforall2018.videohall.com/presentations/1164

Under the Arctic explores the immense scale of Earth's permanently frozen ground and the impact of widespread thawing on Arctic communities and the global climate. Visitors to the exhibition are drawn into the unfamiliar world of permafrost research and thawing landscapes by immersive environments, personal stories from Alaska Natives, and climate change models, metaphors, and solutions. Visitors are invited to explore a replica of the Alaskan research tunnel, investigate the impact of thawing permafrost in Field Lab activities, and engage with local impacts and community responses to climate change.

The exhibition was installed at OMSI in Winter 2017 and evaluated with museum visitors in Spring 2018. Independent evaluation by the Goldstream Group found that the exhibition was highly engaging for visitors. The majority of visitors reported they learned some or a lot about permafrost and problems caused by its thawing. One third of the surveyed visitor groups increased their positive perceptions of community solutions to reduce carbon emissions or adapt to climate change impacts. The full evaluation report is posted here: https://omsi.edu/museum-services/evaluations

An additional informal assessment was provided by Kathayoon Kahlil, Principal Evaluator at the Seattle Aquarium, who visited the exhibition at OMSI and wrote a review for Curator. Dr. Kahlil found the personal stories from Alaska Natives especially powerful. She wrote, "This exhibition excels at presenting diverse voices in a complicated conversation, a difficult task that OMSI has met with creativity."

Christie Collins, science educator the first tour venue, the Children's Science Explorium in Boca Raton, FL, sent OMSI this comment about the exhibition and the real permafrost ice sample, "Thank you again, this has been our favorite and best exhibit to date!"

During its 11-month venue (November 2017 to October 2018) at OMSI,Under the Arctic was viewed by an estimated 453,915 visitors. The national tour, which began in Boca Raton in January 2019, is expected to last eight years and reach over two million visitors at 24 additional venues.
